discussion.content: Could the technician have chosen either channel 1 or 6 as well, given that 1, 6, and 11 are the channels with the least interference?
Please can someone explain this? Thanks

comments.content: Thanks for the common sense response
I believe it's because she wanted a channel which would not interfere with her neighbors' Wi-Fi. They have theirs at channels 3 & 5. Channel 11 would be a good choice to avoid signal conflict.

discussion.content: Hi guys..can someone explain why channel 11 was chosen in the solution please? Thanx in advance

Selected Answer: C
C. It's duplexing, no other answer is possible here. Also its just fact lmao

comments.content: Duplex specifically refers to printing on both sides of the paper. Collating is the order in which the pages are printed. C is the answer

discussion.content:
Where Duplex is not available , collate is the best.
Again very relative answer

As a Tech, one of the best things you can do is explain terms like collate or duplex to office workers. Train them! Issues like "How do I print..." will come up thousands of times unless you take proactive steps to make your coworkers sufficient. It's totally acceptable to create a powerpoint, send an email, write a document, or whatever is neccesary to explain different systems and technology. As a rule, realize that if you don't train your staff. They won't learn it themselves. Often they'll continue poor habits or waste time and resources (Printing on one side, not doing collated). Simple things like this go a long way. The same goes for Office products, Windows 10, Email systems. Think through what a person needs to know on Day one to be sufficient and start communicating that. Overcommunicate. It'll save you tons of time solving problems that could have been avoided.

questions.question_text:
A user wants to print a large job on both the front and back sides of the paper.
Which of the following settings should the technician advise the user to change in the printer settings?

comments.content: Because he is connecting it to the company

discussion.content: Why is this not LAN? It's at home.

I believe this picture helps sum it up quite a bit.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_area_network#/media/File:Data_Networks_classification_by_spatial_scope.svg

Don't worry about if the ISP is in the same city or not it doesn't matter. You are connecting a modem to an Internet Service Provider. The internet is a WAN. It's only a MAN if the network itself doesn't go any further than the city area.

comments.content: I would say that this is fair to assume. The question never states that the ISP is located in the same city, so I believe it is easier to assume that it is not.
MAN = Metropolitan Area Network, does it not? Should this be assumed that the SOHO is setup outside of the city? How does multiple ISPs in the city justify WAN?
There are multiple ISPs in the city, hence not a MAN.
ISP are WAN (multi-city, multi-region, multi-country, multi-continent) therefore connecting to an ISP means you are connecting to a WAN.

discussion.content: Why would this not be MAN? The network is still located in the same city

questions.question_text: A user sets up a cable modem at home and connects the modem to the ISP at the cable company. Which of the following network types does this connection describe?

discussion.content: The company email is on a default non secure ports. Which means the port numbers should be the none secure ports. pop3 110 , imap 143 and smtp 25 . There are several secure ports you can pick from but these are the only non secure port numbers

questions.question_text:
SIMULATION -
You need to configure your mobile device to send and receive electronic messages from your company.
You must use the company's WLAN as all e-mail services are on default non-secure ports.
The company's WLAN is broadcasting across the company for easier access. Both incoming and outgoing servers require login credentials.
Use the following parameters:
* Email address tech@techies com
* Password P@SSwOrd
* Pop techies com Port 110 Security. None
* IMAP techies com Port 993 Security SSL
* smtp.techies.com Port 465 Security: TLS
* Company SSID Techies
* Security WPA2
* Passphrase P@SSwOrd
* SSID is not broadcasted
INSTRUCTIONS:
Update the mobile device's parameters to fit the criteria.
If at any time you would like to bring back the initial state of the simulation, please click the Reset All button.
//IMG//

A technician receives a cellular call from a manager. The technician is instructed to download a service manual directly from the Internet to a laptop. However, there is no WiFi signal or wired Ethernet. Which of the following would be the MOST appropriate connections for the technician to use?

discussion.content: Read the question properly, it says "No wifi signals", means there is no wifi internet available to connect, in this case you can use hotspot to connect wifi and download the manual,.
NFC cannot be used as it cannot connect the device to the Internet. A hotspot can and the laptop can use it.
B. NFC is the correct answer.
Si no hay señal de wifi ni por cable, entonces como va entrar a internet?

comments.content: Tenemos que usar NFC, por su puesto.
